entry.title: Re: Pricing procedure in Purchase Contracts
entry.content:
As per standard behaviour, in Purchase Contracts, the unit price of the material is determined primarily by the gross price condition (PB00/PBXX or custom ZB00). Supplementary conditions (discounts, surcharges, freight, etc.) maintained in the calculation schema (RM0002 or custom ZM0002) do not change the base unit price of the material. Instead, they are applied as additional values during price determination in follow-on documents (RFQs, Purchase Orders, etc.). This means, it is expected system behavior that supplementary conditions do not directly alter the contract’s item-level unit price. They are considered only when the contract is referenced in a PO or RFQ.

Why Supplementary Conditions don’t impact Unit Price is because of the following:

Contract pricing logic:
Contracts store the agreed gross price per material. Supplementary conditions are stored but not rolled into the displayed “unit price.”

Calculation schema design:
The schema RM0002 (or your ZM0002) applies supplementary conditions in pricing simulations, but the contract document itself shows only the gross/base condition as the unit price.

System consistency:
SAP keeps the contract unit price stable to avoid confusion, while supplementary conditions flow into transactional documents where actual net price is calculated.

So in short, if your business requirement is to see them reflected in the contract’s unit price, you must customize the pricing procedure or write a routine to include them.

entry.title: Re: Bill of services from Projects-CJ20N.
entry.content:
Instead of treating trucks as externally procured services, you can model them as internal resources within Project System and integrate with Controlling.

How it works:

Define Activity Types in CO
Create activity types for truck usage (e.g., “Truck Hours”). Assign cost centers representing the fleet or vehicle groups. Maintain planned/actual rates (cost per hour).

Use Internal Activities in PS Network/Project
Assign internal activities to the project network or WBS elements. Capture actual hours worked by each truck against the project. Hours can be entered manually or via CATS (Cross‑Application Time Sheet).

Settlement & Billing
Actual truck hours posted as activity allocations flow into PS. Resource‑related billing can then pick up these internal activity postings and generate customer invoices. This way, billing is based on internal service consumption rather than external procurement.

Advantages of this approach are

  • Directly maps truck usage as internal effort rather than external services.
  • Granular tracking by vehicle number if you set up cost centers or statistical orders per truck.
  • Weekly/monthly reporting possible via PS/CO reports (hours, costs, utilization).
  • Billing flexibility: You can bill based on hours, rates, or aggregated values.

entry.title: BehaviorInvocationException: Too few values in second queue in function useOneAsMany
entry.content:
Problem Statement

In SAP CPI Message Mapping, I faced a OneAsMany violation due to mismatched occurrences between two source fields:

  • Company Code → Occurrence = 1

  • PRODUCTTAXITEM → Occurrence = 2
    So basically, due to difference in context change, I was not able to use it in value mapping where the target field occurrence is also 2 times, due to this if i use it without OneasMany, it is throwing error : target field require value for it.

This resulted in the following OneAsMany rules being violated:

Rule 1: Input 1 should not contain repeating values in the same context.

Business requirement was to:

  • Increase the context of Company Code

  • Match it with the number of PRODUCTTAXITEM occurrences

  • Repeat only the first Company Code value for all PRODUCTTAXITEM contexts.

    Groovy code used is as follows:

    import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

    // Function name must match the name used in Message Mapping UI
    def void replicateCompanyCode(
    String[] companyCode,
    String[] productTaxItem,
    Output companyCodeOut,
    MappingContext context) {

    // Guard checks
    if (companyCode == null || companyCode.length == 0 ||
    productTaxItem == null || productTaxItem.length == 0) {
    companyCodeOut.addSuppress()
    return
    }

    // Take only the first Company Code
    String firstCompanyCode = companyCode[0]

    // Create context based on PRODUCTTAXITEM count
    for (int i = 0; i < productTaxItem.length; i++) {
    companyCodeOut.addValue(firstCompanyCode)
    companyCodeOut.addContextChange()
    }
    }

    Unit test :

entry.title: A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
entry.content:
A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
CPI also creates context changes automatically when parallel queues advance differently.

What is really happening in your case

You have THREE relevant queues aligned in mapping:

  1. productTaxItem

  2. some other node (likely RECORDTYPE / TaxCode / something parallel)

  3. companyCodeOut (your UDF output)

Your UDF only controls companyCodeOut,
but CPI aligns all queues together.

Notice:

  • companyCodeOut value is SAME (BB01)

  • But another queue changes context (B2 → 22)

CPI inserts an implicit context change to stay aligned with the other node.

So:

  • Context 2 → created by your UDF

  • Context 3 → created automatically by CPI due to parallel node context shift

That’s why they appear together.

entry.title: How to Create a ServiceNow Incident via REST API Using ABAP (OAuth 2.0)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • ServiceNow instance access with API credentials (Client ID, Client Secret)
  • SAP NetWeaver with HTTP Client (CL_HTTP_CLIENT) and JSON support (/UI2/CL_JSON)

Step 1: Obtain OAuth2 Token from ServiceNow

First, you need to POST your client credentials to ServiceNow’s /oauth_token endpoint to get a bearer token. This token authorizes subsequent API calls.

ABAP Code:

FORM get_servicenow_token USING iv_token_url TYPE string
                              iv_client_id TYPE string
                              iv_client_secret TYPE string
                         CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
                                  cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, the access_token can now be used as a Bearer token.

Step 2: Build the JSON Payload

Create a JSON structure that describes the incident.

ABAP Code:

lv_json_body =
'{' &&
'"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
'"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
'"category":"Data",' &&
'"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
'"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"impact":"2",' &&
'"urgency":"2"' &&
'}'.

Step 3: Create the Incident via POST API

Now, make a POST request to the ServiceNow incident table, including your access token for authorization.

ABAP Code:

FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, cv_result will contain the incident response from ServiceNow.

Step 4: Combine the Steps in Your Report

Your main program calls these subroutines in sequence.

Example Main Logic:

* Get the access token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token
               USING lv_token_url
                     lv_client_id
                     lv_client_secret
               CHANGING ls_token
                     lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Create the incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident
                    USING lv_post_url
                          ls_token-access_token
                          lv_json_body
                   CHANGING lv_result
                            lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.

Final Notes

  • Security: Never hardcode sensitive data in productive programs—use secure storage.
  • Error Handling: Always add robust error handling and log failures for troubleshooting.
  • Data Mapping: Adjust JSON fields based on ServiceNow table and your organization’s requirements.

Conclusion

Integrating SAP and ServiceNow allows you to automatically manage ITSM incidents directly from SAP ABAP.  The above example demonstrates OAuth token retrieval and incident creation using ABAP.  Adapt and build on this foundation to suit your business requirements.

Happy Integrating! Let me know in the comments if you have any questions or need clarification on any step.

 

Complete ABAP CODE:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSNOW
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Utility: ServiceNow Incident API Integration
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

REPORT zsnow.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token,
         access_token TYPE string,
         scope        TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
       END OF ty_token.

DATA: lv_token_url     TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/oauth_token',
      lv_client_id     TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-id...',
      lv_client_secret TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-secret...',
      lv_post_url      TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/api/now/table/incident',
      lv_json_body     TYPE string,
      ls_token         TYPE ty_token,
      lv_err           TYPE string,
      lv_result        TYPE string.

* Prepare JSON Body

lv_json_body = '{' &&
               '"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
               '"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
               '"category":"Data",' &&
               '"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
               '"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"impact":"2",' &&
               '"urgency":"2"' &&
               '}'.

* Step 1: Get the Token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token USING lv_token_url
                                   lv_client_id
                                   lv_client_secret
                          CHANGING ls_token
                                   lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Step 2: Create Incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident USING lv_post_url
                                         ls_token-access_token
                                         lv_json_body
                                CHANGING lv_result
                                         lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.



*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Get OAuth Token from ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM get_servicenow_token
  USING    iv_token_url TYPE string
           iv_client_id TYPE string
           iv_client_secret TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " get_servicenow_token

*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Create an Incident in ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " create_servicenow_incident

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB Material Master Consumption Question in SAP P...
entry.content:
Hello @Ashley_Hung

Thanks for your question. The numbers in the Consumption tab are only updated when you post goods issues with movement types that are configured to update “consumption” and when the material has a Forecast view with a period indicator. If your transactions are receipts or issues with movement types that don’t update consumption, or if the Forecast view was created after the postings, the tab will stay at zero.

Common reasons why you see zeros:

1.The postings are not “consumption” postings.Purchase receipts (101), stock transfers (301/311), customer deliveries (601) and many other movement types do not update material master consumption in standard.Typical movement types that DO update consumption in standard are withdrawals such as 201/202 (to cost center), 261/262 (to production order), 281/282 (to project/WBS), 551/552 (scrapping), etc.

2.Forecast view was added after the transactions.MVER is only updated from the moment the Forecast view and period indicator exist. Past postings are not retroactively written to consumption.

3.You are looking at the wrong plant or period.Consumption is plant-specific and period-based. If reversals were posted in the same period, net consumption can be zero.

4.Movement type configuration does not update consumption.If your process uses a custom movement type or a variant whose “Update Consumption in Material Master” flag is off, consumption will not be updated.

Be aware: there is no standard job in S/4HANA Cloud to backfill historical consumption into the material master. If you need history for forecasting, use analytics based on material documents rather than relying on the Consumption tab.

Hope this can help.

Best Regards

Dave

entry.title: FBE1 automation
entry.content:
Hi,
I'm trying to automate FBE1 with quick capture, but I'm continuosly getting Error 344.
What I'm trying to achieve is really simple:
1. Insert requires fields company code (0001), account type (D) and account number (0000001234).
2. Then add The total amount for the payment advice (e.g. 600.00 EUR) 
3. Add all positions through quick capture (Schnellerfassung) with amount (2x 300EUR) and document number (eg. 1234abcd) 

And finally saving it and returning the the new advice number. Below is my code.
Can someone help me identify where the issue comes from?

 

" ---- start bdc

bdc_dynpro( iv_prog = 'SAPMF06A' iv_dynp = '0100' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_OKCODE' iv_fval = '/00' ).

bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_CURSOR' iv_fval = 'RF06A-BUKRS' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'RF06A-BUKRS' iv_fval = '0001' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'RF06A-KOART' iv_fval = 'D' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'RF06A-KONTO' iv_fval = '0000001234' ).

bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_OKCODE' iv_fval = '=WEIT' ).

" --- Advice Head
bdc_dynpro( iv_prog = 'SAPLFRAD' iv_dynp = '0200' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_CURSOR' iv_fval = 'AVIK-WAERS' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'AVIK-WAERS' iv_fval = 'EUR' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_CURSOR' iv_fval = 'AVIK-WRBTR' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'AVIK-WRBTR' iv_fval = '600.00' ). " conv bdc_fval( iv_total ) ).

" ----- Add positions
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_CURSOR' iv_fval = 'GS_AVIP_FAST_ENTRY-NEBTR(01)' ).

LOOP AT it_positions ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_pos>).
DATA(lv_idx2) = |{ lv_index WIDTH = 2 PAD = '0' ALIGN = RIGHT }|. " '01', '02', ...

bdc_dynpro( iv_prog = 'SAPLFRAD' iv_dynp = '0200' ).

bdc_field( iv_fnam = |GS_AVIP_FAST_ENTRY-BELNR(01)| iv_fval = conv bdc_fval( <ls_pos>-belnr ) ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = |GS_AVIP_FAST_ENTRY-NEBTR(01)| iv_fval = '300.00' ).

bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_OKCODE' iv_fval = '/00' ).

lv_index = lv_index + 1

ENDLOOP.

" ---- saving data
bdc_dynpro( iv_prog = 'SAPLFRAD' iv_dynp = '0200' ).
bdc_field( iv_fnam = 'BDC_OKCODE' iv_fval = '=BU' ).

Data: lt_msg TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bdcmsgcoll.

CALL TRANSACTION 'FBE1'
USING gt_bdc
MODE 'N'
UPDATE 'S'
MESSAGES INTO lt_msg.

entry.title: Re: Disable download statement button in compensation wor...
entry.content:
HI, Isn`t it the option related to the Enable Bulk Print in Executive Review.

Enable Bulk Print in Executive Review: When this setting is ticked, users can view the Bulk Print Statement icon on the Salary, Stock, and Bonus tabs on the Executive Review page, based on the includeStatementLink attribute set in the XML template. Users can then download Compensation, Variable Pay and Combined statements in PDF format for the filtered employees.

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB PIR Update in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @Ashley_Hung ,

Thanks for your question.

That is standard system behavior. The “Update Purchasing Info Record” indicator on a supplier quotation is designed to immediately write the quoted price (including validity dates and conditions) into the purchasing info record as soon as the quotation is saved/posted in S/4HANA, independent of whether you have awarded that quotation. The award decision is a separate business step (used to drive follow-on PO creation and internal status), but it is not a technical prerequisite for PIR updates.

Why SAP does it this way

  • The PIR is the central source of supply/price for future POs and price determination. SAP’s default logic keeps it current with the latest valid quotation so buyers always see the newest price/validity when creating POs, contracts, etc.
  • The award is a purchaser decision step; it does not change the fact that a vendor has provided a valid price and validity period. SAP separates “information maintenance” (PIR) from “sourcing decision” (award/accept).

What actually triggers the update

  • When you save/post the supplier quotation and the item has “Update Info Record” selected, S/4HANA writes the price and validity to the PIR right then.
  • It does not wait for “Accept/Award” in the RFQ/quotation comparison step.

How to change or avoid this if you only want PIR updates after award

  • Process practice: Leave “Update Purchasing Info Record” unchecked during the RFQ/quotation stage. Only update the PIR from the follow-on PO you create for the awarded supplier (use the “Info Update” indicator on the PO item so the PIR is updated from the PO price), or update the PIR manually after award.
  • Configuration (Cloud): Set the default for quotations to “No info update.”
    • Manage Your Solution > Configure Your Solution > Defaults for Purchasing (SSCUI for default values). Set the default for “Quotation – Info Update” to no update so buyers don’t accidentally update PIRs at quote stage.
  • Governance option: If you still want to capture quote prices but prevent unintended use, you can block the PIR (Purchasing block) until the award, or ensure the quote validity dates are tight/short so they don’t affect POs before you decide.

Additional recommendations

  • Consider storing negotiated prices in contracts/outline agreements for the awarded supplier rather than relying solely on PIRs. Contracts give better control over validity and adoption.
  • If multiple vendor quotes exist, be mindful that the last quotation that updates the PIR will overwrite previous prices. Use validity dates or a block to avoid unintended adoption.

Hope this can help.

Best Regards

Dave

entry.title: Program Settings: Apply Gates and Accelerators
entry.content:
Hi Everyone, can someone give a practical example (business reason) for what goal gates and accelerators are used and how they can be included in a business case?  

And what is the difference between the Gates and Accelerators, and Curves?

Based on the academy, course the definition is: 

Gates and Accelerators - Overview Gates: Generally defined as some minimum performance level that must be met to receive payout on an associated goal, component (section), or the entire plan. Often tied to the incentive plan’s funding mechanism, such as revenue goals, and are used to ensure that a minimum level of funding is achieved before there is payout. Accelerators: Used to increase the incentive opportunity when certain performance criteria are met or exceeded. When a participant meets their respective accelerator performance criteria target(s), the accelerator can apply to the payout of the individual goal itself, other goals, other incentive components (sections), or the total plan payout.

Gates – Examples Gates define a minimum or threshold level of specific performance criteria that impacts payout on another goal, bonus section, or the plan itself. Gates are most often used in one of two ways. The first is a minimum level of achievement required of a specific business goal to allow for any payout against another. The second is as a threshold level that must be achieved before another goal can exceed payout beyond a certain level. Accelerators Accelerators are another feature often included in incentive plans to focus the participants’ attention on specific goals. They act to accelerate payment of a goal(s) once specific performance criteria have been met.

Example: Accelerator on Goal Payout If specific performance criteria (a business goal) are met or exceeded, the payout opportunity for other business goal(s) increases 2% for each goal that exceeds its target. The accelerator is identified as a specific goal and when this specific goal hits target, it enables the accelerator. Which is a higher payout line for other associated goals when they hit target. 

Regards, Maria

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to transport custom views in applicati...
entry.content:
Good day @Kazuhiro_F 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer to your question is, No, you cannot transport My Views of Manage Sales Orders V2 through Software Collections in public cloud.

The My Views entries like your Test view are Fiori Personalisation. They are not transported through Software Collections to Quality for Production. This is also the case even if you create a public view. The public cloud does not provide the possibility to transport request prompt and you cannot move the view to another system as a standard medium. See KBA 3329053 for more details.

An alternative you may consider if your goal is to have same filter and column layout in every system, then you should:

  • Recreate the view manually in Q and P, or
  • You make use of a key user extensibility artifact that is transportable for example App Variant or Adapt UI change, if your requirement is more than just saving a view.  Key User Extensibility and Transports provides information on Software Collections only being used for key user extensibility object and not for “My Views” end user.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP’s Engagement in the Eclipse IDE Working Group
entry.content:
Since 2021, SAP has been a founding member of the Eclipse IDE Working Group. It was established to ensure the long-term sustainability, integrity, and evolution of Eclipse IDE products. SAP's ABAP Development Tools (ADT) are powered by the robust Eclipse platform, allowing us to leverage its extensive capabilities and flexibility. This strategic choice enables us to innovate rapidly and deliver high-quality solutions. By actively contributing and collaborating, we help shape the platform's future, mitigate potential risks, and guarantee the availability and continuous improvement of the tools our users rely on. This is currently driven by five employees with committer status.

In this article, we would like to reflect on how we were involved with the Eclipse community on behalf of SAP and the Eclipse IDE Working Group.

Looking Back On 2025

This year was a continuation of our collaboration with the Eclipse IDE community. Beyond code contributions, SAP actively participated in various events and initiatives to support and grow the Eclipse community. Key highlights have been:

  • Eclipse shipped four releases of the Desktop IDE and we are proud that some of SAP’s contributions are listed as new and noteworthy changes in the release notes.
  • SAP hosted Eclipse Platform RCP & IDE Open Community Meetups in Germany and India, giving developers, contributors, and enthusiasts a chance to connect. We covered a wide range of topics - from community updates and progress on modernizing the Eclipse UI Toolkit to improvements on performance, security, and user experience. The agenda also included demos from Eclipse Platform committers and SAP experts about new Java features and the IBM Semuru releases, practical Eclipse IDE tips, showcases of AI features in Eclipse-based products, and sessions on improving the contributor experience. Beyond the sessions, informal discussions sparked fresh ideas, proving that open source thrives through shared effort and engagement.
    Meetup in Germany, July 2025

    Meetup in India, September 2025

  • Regular engagement in the IDE working group lead to a very productive collaboration with different working group companies and other project committers, making it possible to contribute major changes such as UI modernizations.
  • To strengthen our commitment and contribution to the Eclipse IDE ecosystem, we upgraded our membership level from "Strategic Member" to the Platinum-level of the Eclipse Foundation’s IDE Working Group in 2025.
  • Sonja Liénard (@lienards), Head of ABAP Platform and true ABAP expert, was interviewed in SAP’s podcast "The Open Source Way", sharing insights into SAP’s history of the ABAP programming language and some open source fun facts, such as even Visual Studio Code using Eclipse for the Java language support. She goes into quite some details on how SAP leverages the Eclipse IDE to provide a comprehensive and flexible development environment for its technologies. Listen to the episode at https://podcast.opensap.info/open-source-way/2025/12/01/abap-and-eclipse/. 

With these activities we aimed to give our share to collaboration and continuous investment to ensure the sustainable evolution and long-term availability of the Eclipse IDE.

Looking Ahead to 2026

Building on this strong momentum, we are looking forward to continuing our open source journey with the community to propel Eclipse forward. In 2026, we also plan to host Open Community Meetups again, providing opportunities to exchange ideas, showcase progress, and strengthen connections across the ecosystem.

Saying Thank You

A big THANKS to all colleagues, community members, and contributors who make Eclipse what it is. Every idea, contribution, and discussion helping keep the platform thriving for years to come.

Let’s keep Eclipse thriving – together!

entry.title: Re: Data retention and RPO for S4 Hana Cloud Public Editi...
entry.content:
Good day @Cheng_Huang58 

Thank you for your question

1. Answer to your question regarding data retention:

Officially your business data stays in the productive tenant for the duration of your subscription. Should you contract come to an end, you have the possibility to export your data before your subscription ends. See GENERAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR CLOUD SERVICES for more details.

If your enquiry is about statutory retention periods, it is typically handled through Information Lifecycle Management. Here you can define retention rules and archiving behaviour.

See the following reference for more details on agreements: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements.html

2. Regarding your question on RPO;

RPO is not something you can configure in your tenant. It is predefined by SAP’s resilience and disaster recovery design for the service. See KBA 3396152 - FAQs about backup and recovery service for S/4HANA Public Cloud Customers. You can check the service availability and resilience information for your productive tenant.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Mastering SAP Enterprise Architecture : A Practical Certification Journey
entry.content:
During my 2025 year-end meetup with mentees, I was asked a lot of questions about the SAP Enterprise Architecture (EA) certification. What surprised me was that the majority of questions weren’t about the theory or technical aspects they were about how to prepare. How do you study? What resources help the most? What’s the exam actually like?

After completing the certification myself, I thought it would be helpful to share what worked for me. This blog answers some of the common questions based on my experience to help anyone preparing for the SAP EA certification.

Q1. What is the SAP EA certification?

SAP Enterprise Architecture (EA) certification is all about understanding how SAP's various solutions fit together in the bigger picture of an organization's IT landscape. It's not just about knowing the individual SAP products, it's about how they all work in harmony to drive business transformation.  More dive into topics like SAP S/4HANA, SAP’s Cloud solutions, SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP BDC and how to leverage them to build scalable, efficient and forward-thinking future ready enterprise systems.

It’s not just about mastering SAP tools but also understanding their strategic value in the context of business operations. It helps to really understand how different modules work together and more importantly, how they can drive value for our customer’s business.

Q2. Who should take SAP EA Certification?

If you’re someone who:

  • Working with SAP solutions or IT architecture, this certification will enhance your expertise.
  • Those aiming to become an Enterprise or SAP Solution Architect,it's perfect for expanding your skills in designing and managing complex systems.
  • Professionals in leadership roles(with strategic mindset)focused on business transformation or IT strategy, this will help you align technology with business needs.
  • Anyone who wants a deeper understanding of SAP's entire ecosystem, not just isolated tools, this certification connects all the dots or someone who wants to understand how SAP is used in real-world enterprise settings.

Q3. Why did I choose to pursue the SAP EA certification?

I’ve been working with SAP for several years and during that time, I realized how important it is to understand not just individual SAP solutions but how they fit together as part of an overall enterprise architecture. In my 2012 SCN Member of the Month interview, I shared how impressed I was by SAP Solutions's ability to solve real-world problems. The SAP EA certification offered me the opportunity to deepen my knowledge of how SAP's various tools and platforms work together to streamline business operations and drive innovation.

For me, it felt like a natural next step. If you're looking to take on a more strategic role in SAP projects, whether as an architect, consultant, or someone leading digital transformation initiatives, this certification provides the knowledge and credibility you need to guide organizations through complex SAP landscapes.

Q4. How did I start preparing for the SAP EA certification, and what study resources helped me the most?

My preparation for the SAP Enterprise Architect (EA) certification began with getting a clear understanding of the exam structure, scope, and core focus areas. I started by reading Preparation Guide for SAP Enterprise Architect which set the foundation for what I needed to know.
Once I had a sense of the areas to focus on, I turned to official SAP learning materials. These resources were my primary go-to:

  • Official SAP Learning Journeys: These are essential and aligned with certification expectations
    • Becoming an SAP Enterprise Architect 
    • Discovering SAP Enterprise Architecture
    • Exploring the sap enterprisearchitecture-framework foundation
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub:  This is Great for exploring “to-be” architectures in different industries.
  • Case Studies Live sessions: I participated in the case study exercises twice to practice analyzing real-world scenarios.
  • SAP EAF Press Book: More detail, even core Focused on merger/acquisition scenarios and two-tier SAP landscapes.
  • BTP Solution Architect Learning Journey:  This learning journey further strengthened my knowledge of integration patterns and platform-based architectures and  Getting certified Live sessions like BTP Solution architect and LeanIX which was extremely useful
  • I simply followed a structured learning approach as outlined in the Learning Journey, which was further emphasized by the Learning Hub coach, who also guided the case study exercises.

Real-world experience also helped a lot. Applying concepts to actual customer scenarios made the learning process practical and relevant.

A key tip:

Don’t skip visuals! Diagrams and images in the learning journeys are crucial for understanding how SAP components interact.

Q5. Did you clear the SAP EA certification on your first attempt?

No, I didn’t pass on my first try. It took me few attempts. I initially approached the SAP EA certification with a TOGAF enterprise architecture mindset.

While TOGAF provides a strong and valuable foundation, it is not sufficient on its own to clear the SAP EA certification. The exam requires a deep and practical understanding of SAP EAF, SAP-specific terminology, reference architectures, and how SAP positions enterprise architecture within real customer scenarios.

After reviewing my score reports, I focused on my weak areas and changed my approach(like deep dive even Diagrams and images in the learning journeys) With targeted prep and persistence, I eventually passed.

Q6. How did I prepare for scenario based questions in the EA certification?

To clear the EA certification, you need more than just memorizing theory. It’s about understanding how architectural choices work in real-world situations. A practical approach includes:

  • Focus on the "why," not just the "what": Understand why certain architectures or strategies are chosen for specific business needs.
  • Connect concepts to real projects: Relate what you’re learning to real scenarios, like S/4HANA migration or cloud integration. This helps you remember the ideas better.
  • Practice with scenario-based questions: Work through case studies and exercises that mirror real business problems.

Common types of practical exam questions:

  • Choosing the right architecture for a business need.
  • Identifying the best integration or deployment options.
  • Evaluating different solutions and making decisions, check the blog about Case for Central finance Services

Moreover, I trained myself to ask:

  • What is the business problem?
  • What solution fits best?
  • Why are other options wrong?

This mindset helped me eliminate wrong answers quickly and focus on the best solution, key to answering scenario-heavy questions.

Q7. Can a fresher or junior consultant do the SAP EA certification?

Yes, but with the right expectations.

For those like my mentees who are still working students:

  • The certification won’t immediately change your job title.
  • But it will set you up for future growth.
  • It helps you stand out in architecture discussions.

Think of it as an investment in your career, not a shortcut.

Q8. How Much Time is Needed to Prepare?

The goal isn’t to race through the material, it’s about truly understanding the concepts. I treated my preparation as a journey, not just an exam. . 

The real focus should be on grasping how everything fits together, not just memorizing facts. Consistency, deep understanding, and applying what you learn in real-world scenarios are the keys to success. Take your time, and the results will follow. 

Focus more on understanding than speed.

Q9. Will an Enterprise Architect job be obtained immediately after the SAP EA Certification?

While the SAP EA certification may not immediately result in an Enterprise Architect position, it is an important step toward that goal. The certification enhances understanding of SAP's solutions and how they integrate into business architecture, making candidates more competitive for future roles.

It builds credibility, strengthens architectural thinking, and opens doors to new opportunities. With the right experience and application of knowledge, this certification lays a strong foundation for career growth.

Q10. What is my final words for SAP EA certification aspirants?

Think beyond certification, use SAP EA as a tool to drive real-world impact. When you see the value we as EA bring to businesses, the certification will feel like just the beginning. 

it's truly a journey that builds you into an architect who can truly shape the future. Keep pushing, and your impact will be limitless.

entry.title: Re: #QDGG#Can we do configuration during S4 upgrading
entry.content:
Good day @ericyu 

Thank you for your question

Yes, you can do configuration on your CBC during S4 upgrading. However, there are clear restrictions on what you can move and when, mainly because your DEV, Q and P systems are on different releases. Check out these Blogs for more details: FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

You can usually continue preparing configuration changes in CBC project for dev, do design an configuration preparation in DEV for the next release, perform regression testing and adjust configurations in upgraded Test system after you have concluded your upgrade. See Navigating Release Upgrades and Test System Upgrade for more details. Note that you may need to wait with the changes until your landscapes are aligned before you can move them forward.

 

Regarding testing and readiness activities, during you upgrade cycle, it is advisable to

  • Use the upgraded Test system first for regression testing, review changes and depreciations after the upgrade. See: Manage Changes and Deprecations After Upgrade and Upgrade Preparation for more information.

 

During your upgrade period, I advise:

  • Not to expect transports to production while releases are mismatched. See KBA 2791664 for more details.
  • Do not schedule your major configuration activation close to the production upgrade weekend. See FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for more insights, and
  • Do not leave CBC transports open across release boundaries. See KBA 3482742

 

This Blog: Mastering the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Release Readiness Check: What Every Customer Should Know provides some vital information.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Stock Values Showing Zero Post Stock Adjustment
entry.content:
Some options to Correct the Stock Valuation

Post a Manual Accounting Adjustment (FI/MM Integration)
Use transaction MR22 (Change Material Valuation) to adjust the value of the stock to the correct amount. This ensures the inventory value reflects the actual procurement cost, even though the PO is closed. MR22 posts directly to stock accounts and offsetting accounts, aligning valuation.

Create a New PO for the Correct Material Number
Raise a new PO for the correct material/finish. Perform a Goods Receipt (GR) against this PO to bring the stock in with the correct value. Then, clear the manually adjusted stock (e.g., issue out the wrongly valued stock and receive against the PO). This way, the stock is properly linked to procurement and valuation flows correctly.

Material-to-Material Transfer (if applicable)
If the incorrect material number and the correct one are related, you can use transaction MB1B (Transfer Posting) with movement type 309 (material-to-material transfer). This moves stock from the old material number to the new one, carrying valuation. However, since the PO is closed and invoice paid, this may not fully resolve valuation unless combined with MR22.

Custom Business Rule (if frequent)
If this scenario happens often, consider defining a custom process in such a way that always raise a PO for corrected materials. Use transfer postings to align stock. Use MR22 only for exceptional cases.

The recommended approach is to execute MR22 to adjust the stock value directly, ff this is a one-off correction. If this is a recurring business process → Raise a new PO for the correct material number and align stock through GR, ensuring procurement and valuation flow correctly.

entry.title: Re: Sales order stock 140001513 000010 does not exist
entry.content:
Why system is triggering that error message is because, the system is telling you “Sales order stock … does not exist”. This happens because the sales order stock is tied to plant 11DB, but the physical stock is in plant 11DA. In SAP, sales order stock is special stock type (E), which is always linked to a specific sales order + plant combination. Since your STO is trying to issue stock from 11DA, but the sales order stock exists only in 11DB, the system cannot find the required stock.

Options to Resolve

Align Plant Assignment
Ensure the sales order is created for the same plant (11DA) where the stock physically exists. If the SO was created for 11DB, but stock is in 11DA, you need to either transfer the stock or adjust the SO plant.

Transfer Posting Between Plants
Use MB1B / MIGO with movement type 301 (plant-to-plant transfer) to move the stock from 11DA to 11DB. Once the stock is in 11DB, the PGI for the STO will work because the sales order stock exists in the correct plant.

Recreate STO with Correct Plant
If the business process requires shipping from 11DA, then the sales order should reference plant 11DA. Recreate the STO cycle with the correct plant assignment so that the sales order stock and STO plant match.

Check Special Stock Assignment
Verify in MD04 (Stock/Requirements List) whether the material is showing under sales order stock for 11DA. If not, you must either transfer or reassign the stock to the correct sales order/plant combination.

entry.title: Re: Shipment Tracking
entry.content:
You have used a tag "Cloud Transport Management" (CTM) which is a tool for managing software transports (moving configuration/code between systems). I don't think, this is related to your issue. If so, please remove this tag

To address the challenge of offline shipment tracking, I recommend leveraging SAP’s logistics capabilities to enable real‑time status updates. One option is to implement SAP Transportation Management (TM), which provides freight order management and allows the transportation team to record shipment milestones such as pickup, in transit, delayed, and delivered directly in SAP. These updates can also be automated through carrier integration, ensuring timely and accurate information flow.

Alternatively, if full TM implementation is not feasible, you can use embedded shipment documents in SAP S/4HANA. By linking shipments to STOs/POs, the transportation team can manually update status fields within SAP, giving stakeholders visibility into progress without relying on offline records.

Both approaches ensure that shipment statuses are captured centrally in SAP, improving transparency, streamlining billing and follow‑up processes, and enhancing customer satisfaction.

entry.title: Re: Extract Report for Workflow Approver
entry.content:
Hello @sans16 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud operational apps (such as Manage Purchase Order / Purchase Requisition / Service Entry sheet) do not provide approved by user filter. This functionality sits in the workflow task and not as a standard filed on the list report you can select.

So, yes, the public cloud offers your client the possibility to produce an audit list of items that are approved by a specific user and items currently waiting with a specific user by using Flexible Workflow Administration and or workflow task CDS based reporting. See Flexible Workflow Administration for more details.

Although the public cloud allows you to export results to spreadsheets from Fiori list pages/analytical queries, a single standard report for PO+PR+SES+all objects is not delivered as a one ready made app. I suggest you use:

  • Workflow instance monitoring (you can set the status, approver, date of completion, etc.) or
    • You can then export to download the generated list for any desired user.

  • You create a custom analytical query which is based on released workflow CDS views and filter by workflow scenario.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Negative stock in WM
entry.content:
Hi @LFRANCISCO ,
Negative stock in SAP WM usually happens when postings are inconsistent between MM and WM. To fix it, you’ll need to manually reconcile the WM stock by either creating a corrective transfer posting (LT10/LT01) or adjusting via inventory count (LX22/LX23), ensuring the warehouse is properly configured for the movement type.

The reason for appearing negative stock in WM is, Mismatch between MM and WM postings: Your MM reversal worked, but WM didn’t mirror it. If you have custom movement types, and the warehouse wasn’t configured for that movement, WM didn’t update. There can be incomplete transfer orders, Sometimes TOs are created but not confirmed, leaving WM stock negative. Posting sequence errors can cause WM to show stock that MM doesn’t.

To correct it the negative stock you can use any of the option mentioned below.

Option 1. Check Stock Situation
Use LX02 or LS24 to confirm the negative stock at storage bin level. Verify if there are open transfer orders (LT24) that might be stuck.

Option 2. Perform Inventory Adjustment
Run LX22 (Inventory Differences) or LX23 (Batch Differences). Post a physical inventory count to bring WM stock back to zero. This is the safest way if MM stock is already correct.

Option 3. Manual Transfer Posting
Use LT10/LT01 to move stock into the negative bin. Create a dummy positive posting in WM (without affecting MM) to offset the negative. Then clear it with a corrective transfer order.

Option 4. Reconfigure Movement Types
Ensure the custom movement type is linked to the warehouse in OMJJ/OMLW. Missing configuration is often the root cause. Once fixed, future postings won’t create negative stock.

Hope the option may help you to fix the issue.

entry.title: Re: SAP SD Plant Rollout – Configuration Scope & Common P...
entry.content:
When introducing a new plant, you need to ensure the following SD-relevant settings are in place:

Organizational Assignments
Assign the new plant to the correct sales organization, distribution channel, and division. Ensure the plant is linked to the company code and valuation area.

Shipping Point Determination
Define shipping points and assign them to the new plant. Configure shipping conditions, loading groups, and transportation groups.

Availability Check / ATP
Set up checking groups and rules for the new plant. Ensure material master data has proper MRP and availability settings.

Pricing Procedure Determination
Confirm that sales area + plant combinations are covered in pricing determination. Check condition records for freight, surcharges, or plant-specific pricing.

Output Management
Configure billing and delivery outputs for the new plant. Ensure forms/templates are aligned with customer requirements.

Partner Functions & Master Data
Verify customer master data includes the new plant for shipping and delivering. Update material master views (sales org, plant-specific storage, etc.).

Integration with MM/PP
Ensure procurement and production views are aligned. Stock transport orders and intercompany flows often need special attention.


Common Pitfalls During Testing / Go-Live

From rollout experience, here are the most frequent issues:

  • Incomplete Master Data: Materials missing plant-specific sales views, or customers not extended to the new plant.
  • Shipping Point Errors: Deliveries fail because shipping point determination is not correctly maintained.
  • ATP Failures: Availability check not working due to missing configuration or incorrect checking group.
  • Pricing Gaps: Condition records not maintained for the new plant, leading to zero or incorrect pricing.
  • Output Issues: Delivery/billing documents not generating outputs because output determination was not extended.
  • Cutover Data Quality: Incorrect stock balances or open orders migrated, causing reconciliation issues.
  • Intercompany Billing: If the new plant is cross-company, missing intercompany pricing and billing setup.

entry.title: Navigating consent: legal and ethical perspectives on transparency
entry.content:
Introduction

In aviation, pre-flight checklists and safety briefings are non-negotiable—a point Abhishek emphasized in his recent post on AI safety ( Engineering AI Safety part 1 and Engineering AI Safety part 2 ). For AI, the concept of “safety” extends beyond technical boundaries to include ethical and legal dimensions, and consent is a critical part of that equation. Just as pilots rely on checklists before takeoff, AI systems need transparent and robust consent mechanisms before engaging in digital interactions.

In particular, consent in AI interactions presents a growing challenge: users often engage with intelligent systems without realizing it, and when consent is requested, it is frequently vague, overly technical, or legally insufficient. This lack of clarity can lead to unintended data use, privacy risks, and erosion of trust. Consider a common use case: a customer interacting with a virtual assistant that collects behavioral data to improve service. Without clear disclaimers or meaningful consent mechanisms, the user may unknowingly agree to data processing that affects their rights. This scenario highlights the urgent need for transparent, accessible, and informed consent structures that reflect the dynamic nature of AI and empower individuals to make conscious decisions.

 

1. Safety instructions before takeoff: understanding consent, the foundation of agreement

Before any flight, it is imperative for passengers to comprehend the safety instructions, which are meticulously reiterated by flight attendants on every journey without exception. This is the basis to equip all passengers appropriately in any situation.

Similarly, consent in AI necessitates the same level of clarity and understanding before 'takeoff'—a clear explication is crucial to enable informed decision-making

Consent can be defined as "to agree to something or give your permission for something" (Oxford English Dictionary) or as "permission or agreement; the state of agreeing with someone or something." (Cambridge Dictionary). Consent often involves synonyms such as accept, approve, and go along with, but it is not just that: it is a shared decision-making process. However, the essence of consent lies not only in agreeing to something but in understanding precisely what is being accepted.

To ensure valid and informed consent, while each country has specific national regulations, there are universal requirements that must be met in all cases, including:

  • Capacity: Individuals must be of legal age and possess the mental maturity to fully understand what they are consenting to.
  • Voluntary agreement: Consent must be given freely, without any form of coercion, manipulation, or deception.
  • Clear content: The subject of consent must be clearly defined and easily understandable. This is crucial for ensuring that individuals fully grasp the nature and implications of what they are agreeing to.
  • Form: Depending on the nature of what is being consented to, specific forms or procedures may be required according to applicable laws and standards, e.g. consent provided in the written form may be required.
 

2. Flight path and destination clarity: the scope of consent, what are you agreeing to?

In aviation, it's crucial to define flight paths and destinations clearly before takeoff, ensuring a smooth and safe journey.

Consent is a fundamental element in various contexts, ranging from traditional contracts and personal data processing including cookies, to modern interactions with AI.

The evolution of AI has introduced new dynamics in the realm of consent, often involving personal data that fuels AI models, leading to complex legal landscapes and ethical dilemmas. As AI technologies become increasingly integrated into our lives, individuals may unknowingly consent to the use of their personal data, resulting in privacy breaches and potential misuse of information.

Therefore, disclaimers play a crucial role by providing the necessary information for individuals to consciously decide what they are consenting to. Without effective disclaimers, individuals risk consenting to broad or vague terms that may allow their data to be used in unintended ways. For instance, personal data could be used to train AI models for purposes not originally agreed upon, leading to ethical concerns and legal repercussions. Consequently, legal professionals must offer clear guidance on how legal notices and disclaimers must be structured and understood, ensuring they are comprehensible and that those consenting do so in a prior, free, and informed manner.

i. Aircraft documentation and permits: consent to personal data processing

Aircrafts require comprehensive documentation and necessary permits to fly, ensuring all safety and regulatory standards are met. In a similar vein, data processing demands formalized and documented consent, safeguarding compliance with legal standards and securing data integrity.

Before the rise of AI-specific regulations, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) stood as a cornerstone for data protection in the EU, offering a robust framework for consent related to personal data processing.

Under GDPR, consent is defined in Article 4 as a "freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes, signified by a statement or a clear affirmative action."

And Article 7 elaborates on the conditions under which consent is valid, highlighting the importance of clarity, documentation, and the subject's right to withdraw consent with ease.

Further insights are provided in Recital 32, which underscores the need for a clear affirmative act to establish consent, cautioning against methods like silence or pre-ticked boxes.  Recital 42 insists on intelligibility, accessibility, and fairness in consent declarations, emphasizing the necessity for the data subject to have genuine choice and awareness of processing purposes.

Details on SAP’s commitment to safeguarding data protection and privacy that goes beyond mere GDPR compliance can be found here https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/data-privacy.html. 

ii.  Autopilot vs. Human control: consent to interact with AI

Users must know when AI is “piloting” decisions and what risks that entails.

The contemporary challenge lies in ensuring individuals understand interaction with AI. Several barriers exist to obtaining valid consent in this arena:

  • Clarity in terms: Terms and conditions must be clear, concise, and devoid of jargon. Ambiguous language can place individuals in a vulnerable spot, as most people tend to skim through agreements without thorough understanding.
  • Complexity of technology: Explaining AI technology—how data is captured and trained, the workings of algorithms for example—is inherently challenging. People interacting with AI are often not specialists and may struggle to fully comprehend the technicalities.
  • Dynamic nature of AI: AI systems, especially those with machine learning capabilities, continually evolve. Static explanations cannot capture the adaptive nature of AI technologies, which may change the scope and impact of consent over time.
  • Duration of consent: Granting indefinite consent poses issues, given AI's evolving landscape. Consent today reflects current technological conditions, which could subsequently change. While periodic consents are recommended to account for technological advancements, it is crucial to ensure that re-confirming consent is not merely a formality without substance. The reasons and changes behind each request for consent should be explained clearly and meaningfully, so users understand the value and importance of their informed consent.
  • Awareness of AI interaction: Individuals should be clearly informed when they are interacting with an AI system. Without this awareness, users might misinterpret AI-generated content as being human-driven, which could lead to misunderstandings or misplaced trust.

Challenges when using AI that users should be aware of include:  

  • AI hallucinations: AI can produce false or misleading information, known as hallucinations. Users must be made aware of this possibility, ensuring that their consent to interact with AI includes acknowledgment of these risks to avoid confusion or manipulation, they accept a need to verify the system output before further use.
  • Bias in AI: AI systems can harbor biases, impacting the neutrality and fairness of outputs. Such biases can affect humans in significant ways, altering perceptions and decisions based on skewed information.

Automated Decision-Making (ADM) and profiling: individuals have the right not to be subjected to decisions made solely by automated processes, including profiling, that have legal or similarly significant effects. Consent to interact with AI can lead to serious legal and personal consequences if it involves ADM. Users should be aware that AI systems may make decisions impacting their rights, such as credit approvals or job evaluations, without human intervention. Ensuring informed consent means clearly explaining these potential outcomes and allowing individuals to opt-out or request human oversight where possible. Each of these aspects underscores the essential role of transparency in interactions with AI systems. Transparency not only fosters trust and understanding among users but also ensures that consent is informed, relevant, and reflective of the evolving nature of technology. By prioritizing clarity, awareness, and regular updates on AI functionality and potential risks, we uphold the principle of transparency, which is crucial for ethical and effective engagement with AI technologies.

Understanding these complexities is pivotal for legal professionals guiding stakeholders through the intricacies of consent in digital and AI-driven environments.

Not only from a legal but also from an ethical perspective, the risks that AI automation and autonomy pose to individuals are important to consider: In SAP’s AI Ethics Governance process, use cases that involve automated decision making need to specifically prove that this doesn’t entail significant harm for individuals (see AI Ethics Handbook, chapter AI Ethics Assessment Process).

 

3. International frameworks: navigating the regulation of AI consent

Global aviation relies on ICAO standards to ensure safe flights across all skies—AI needs similar international frameworks to guarantee transparency and informed consent in any digital “airspace.”

In the rapidly evolving sphere of AI, numerous international regulations, recommendations, and codes of conduct are shaping the landscape of consent. This comprehensive set of guidelines aims to ensure ethical AI interaction and transparency.

Some the most notable frameworks are EU AI Act, UNESCO's Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, EU's Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI, OECD AI Principles, Code of Conduct for AI Developers under the Hiroshima AI Process, Code of Practice for the AI Act, among others.

Summary of international requirements:

The global standards for consent in AI focus on several key principles:

  • Ensuring humans are aware they are interacting with AI systems, such as chatbots or digital assistants, by clearly stating their AI nature.
  • Providing clear and distinguishable identification of AI upon first interaction.
  • Utilizing mechanisms such as labels or disclaimers, akin to widely recognized symbols or logos.
  • Meeting accessibility requirements for vulnerable populations.
  • Aligning biometric data processing with GDPR protocols to safeguard emotions or intentions.
  • Facilitating human interaction options when essential for upholding fundamental rights, particularly in the context of ADM processes.
  • Recognizing exceptions, such as obviousness to informed users or for criminal investigations.

These international guidelines establish a cohesive ethical and transparent framework for AI consent, paving the way for responsible AI deployment and fostering trust across diverse demographics.

Transparency is a foundational principle across international AI ethics frameworks. While explicit consent is required in certain contexts, many regulations recognize that transparency obligations may be fulfilled through clear AI notices or disclosures. Guidelines from bodies such as UNESCO, the OECD, and the European Commission emphasize the importance of informing individuals when interacting with AI systems, explaining how decisions are made, and ensuring that AI processes are traceable and understandable. These measures aim to safeguard human rights and foster trust in AI technologies.

 

4. Recommendations: crafting effective disclaimers for valid consent

To achieve valid consent in AI interactions, it is crucial to address both the clarity of communication and user understanding, and therefore, it is necessary to be transparent.

Here are key recommendations to ensure that disclaimers are effective and consent is valid:

Prioritize clarity and simplicity

  • Use clear language: Employ straightforward, accessible language that avoids technical jargon. The goal is to ensure that users of all backgrounds – the average person- can easily understand the information presented.
  • Concise disclaimers: Keep disclaimers brief but comprehensive. Focus on delivering essential information that captures the nature of AI interactions and any implications they may have. A valuable initiative to consider is the proposal by the Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, which suggests that terms of service be presented in a single page, containing no more than 500 words.

Enhance transparency

  • Explain AI functionality: Clearly describe how the AI system processes data, makes decisions, and its intended use.
  • Identify AI systems: Ensure that AI systems are explicitly identified as such, confirming users are aware they are interacting with non-human technology.

Facilitate informed consent

  • Provide explanations on impact: Offer insights into how AI interactions might affect users, including potential impacts on rights or safety.
  • Accessibility features: Consider accessible formats that cater to diverse populations, ensuring that all users, including vulnerable groups, can access and understand the information provided.
  • Nudging?

Guarantee flexibility and options

  • Offer alternatives: When possible, provide options for human interaction to comply with fundamental rights and cater to user preferences.
  • Revisit consent periodically: AI technology evolves rapidly; regular reassessments of consent validity are recommended. Periodic renewal of consent ensures alignment with current technological conditions.

Address ethical standards

  • Commit to transparency: Continuously update and refine the transparency measures as outlined in international ethical guidelines to maintain trust and uphold accountability.

Implementing these recommendations helps ensure that user consent, particularly in AI interactions, is valid, informed, and ethically sound. They are also used legally and in appropriate situations, forming the basis for crafting disclaimers that are both effective in legal contexts and respectful of user rights and autonomy.

SAP employs two fundamental design patterns to uphold the transparency principle for end-users interacting with AI: (i) AI Acknowledgment at SAP, which appears when a user accesses the AI feature and typically provides information about the service, terms, and conditions:

and (ii) AI Notice at SAP, located near every AI feature output within our cloud services, usually featuring the language: “Created with AI. Verify before use.”:

Closing

Every flight ends with a safe landing and a post-flight review—AI consent should follow the same principle: conclude with clarity and prepare for the next journey.

Consent in AI is much more than a legal formality—it’s a dynamic process that requires clear communication, genuine user understanding, and ongoing transparency. As AI systems become more integrated into daily life, it’s essential that users are fully aware when they interact with AI, understand the implications of their consent, and have real options to control their data and experiences. International standards and regulations increasingly reflect these priorities, making transparency and user empowerment central to responsible AI.

In the next post, we’ll continue exploring new challenges and practical solutions around transparency in AI—stay tuned for more insights, and keep_the_blue_side_up

References / further reading

AI Transparency Blogpost Series

  • Introductory Blogpost:  Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI through transparency (Responsible AI blogpost series) - SAP Community - Laugwitz, Bettina
  • Explainability Blogpost: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligence understandable  - SAP Community - Laugwitz, Bettina
  • Engineering AI Safety Blogpost (part 1): Engineering AI Transparency: Ideation and validation (Part 1) - SAP Community - Pant, Abhishek
  • Engineering AI Safety Blogpost (part 2):  Engineering AI Transparency: From Build to Operations (Part 2)  - SAP Community - Pant, Abhishek

Regulations and governance frameworks

  • The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32016R0679
  • EU AI Act. https://artificialintelligenceact.eu
  • Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence (UNESCO), https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000380455
  • EU Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI. https://op.europa.eu/en/publication-detail/-/publication/d3988569-0434-11ea-8c1f-01aa75ed71a1
  • AI principles (OECD) AI principles | OECD
  • Code of Conduct for AI Developers under Hiroshima AI Process. https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/library/hiroshima-process-international-code-conduct-advanced-ai-systems
  • UNESCO Ethics of Artificial Intelligence. The Recommendation https://www.unesco.org/en/artificial-intelligence/recommendation-ethics#:~:text=The%20use%20of%20AI%20systems,may%20result%20from%20such%20uses.&text=Unwanted%20harms%20(safety%20risks)%20as,and%20addressed%20by%20AI%20actors.

entry.title: Re: Error durin inventory
entry.content:
I faced a similar issue : I had created an inventory document for multiple bins and, for any reason, one of the bins was not displayed from the LI11N. So the situation was the following : from the LS02N, the bin was displayed with a status "not counted" but it was impossible to add the counting from LI11N.
When I tried to use the "New item" from LI11N for this bin, I got the error L4 050 "Storage bin xxxx excluded from entry" : this was consistent because the bin was already in the inventory document.
I managed to solve the issue by using the old LI11 transaction : with that transaction, th not counted bin was displayed and I was able to enter the counting.

entry.title: SAP DM ST2300 - Use of ESEF transformation registry version 5
entry.content:
Hi Marc_Kuipers,

I have a question regarding one guidelin from ESEF Reporting Manual Preparation of Annual Financial Reports in ESEF format (Update October 2025).

Guidance 2.2.3 Transformation of facts [last updated: October 2025] Whenever a string or numeric text used in an issuer’s report does not follow the format based on the predefined data type of taxonomy element used to mark up such string or numeric text, a transformation rule shall be applied.

For that purpose, ESMA recommends applying the Transformation Rules Registry 5, as published by XBRL International on the dedicated website or any more recent versions of the Transformation Rules Registry provided with a ‘Recommendation’ status at XBRL International.

Question: When will the Registry 5 selection option be available in SAP DM?

‘https://www.xbrl.org/Specification/inlineXBRL-transformationRegistry/REC-2022-02-16/inlineXBRL-transformationRegistry-REC-2022-02-16.html

The manual indicates that the use of Registry 4 is still correct.

However, the customer expects information on this subject.

We are working on version ST2300.

Regards,

Iwona

entry.title: Material Ledger handling for Group Valuation (4G) when not used functionally - S/4HANA Cloud, Public
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We are reviewing how Material Ledger should be handled when Group Valuation (5W2) is technically active but not required from a business or reporting perspective.

We are aware that Group Valuation cannot be technically deactivated once it is activated.
However, we would like to clarify the behavior specifically from a Material Ledger perspective.

In the current system, Group Valuation will not be used from a business or reporting perspective. There is only one company code in the system, and no group-level valuation is required.

Our question is:
Is there any configuration or recommended approach in Material Ledger to avoid operational processing for the 4G (Group Valuation) ledger, even though Group Valuation remains technically active?

More specifically:

  • Can the Material Ledger be configured so that 4G does not require an actual costing run (CKMLCP) in each period?

  • If CKMLCP must technically run for all ML valuation views, is there a way to execute it in a minimal or neutral way for 4G (for example, without price differences or business impact)?

We are looking for best practices to minimize period-end effort related to Group Valuation when it is not used functionally.

BR,
Evrim
